channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Australia all at sea on submarine cable risks
item.description: Aging fleets and a leadership void threaten the country's subsea cable resilience.

item.title: The Challenges of Providing Humanitarian Aid
item.description: Organizations working in Gaza and Sudan say their jobs have become harder than ever.

item.title: Pacific Islands: “Friends to all” is no longer pragmatic
item.description: A changing geopolitical climate means the region must work together first before looking outside for help.

item.title: Why more American seniors are getting high
item.description: No age group is taking up cannabis faster

item.title: Trump Ramps Up the Pressure on Maduro
item.description: The U.S. seizure of an oil tanker near Venezuela marks a new escalation in the White House’s regime-change ambitions.

item.title: Trump Accelerates U.S. Pressure Campaign on Venezuela
item.description: The U.S. seizure of an oil tanker near Venezuela marks a new escalation in the White House’s regime-change ambitions.

item.title: Putin’s Already Won
item.description: He’s exposed fatal divisions in the “West” even as Russians still back his Ukraine invasion.

item.title: Trump’s National Security Strategy Is a Blueprint for the Demise of the West
item.description: The White House’s agenda may not be coherent, but it is deeply dangerous.

item.title: Trump’s Ethnonational Security Strategy
item.description: The United States’ new National Security Strategy is a tissue of populist ideology that reflects no understanding of the real challenges facing the country and views the main threat as liberal democracy itself. The result will be bad for most Americans and their European allies, but highly beneficial for financiers, tech billionaires, racists, and authoritarian powers, especially Russia and China.

item.title: The Big Picture
Two Cheers for the National Security Strategy
item.description: Trump’s new document gets much right and a few things wrong.

item.title: The Geopolitics of Sovereign Wealth Funds
item.description: Countries like Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates are investing capital right when the world values geopolitical swing states.

item.title: The Global Economy’s Hidden Rebalancing
item.description: Although the global growth rate in 2026 is projected to be almost the same as it was in 2025, the headline figure belies deeper structural shifts in capital flows and comparative advantage. These shifts are the real story, because they are quietly reshaping how global savings and investment interact over the coming decade.

item.title: How Global AI Governance Could Work
item.description: Societies differ in their views on privacy, experimentation, market openness, and safety, so no single regulatory model can ever accommodate everyone’s preferences. But a shared architectural foundation based on certain core principles would give every country the flexibility to strike its own balance between risk and innovation.

item.title: Russia’s Blackout Warfare Needs a U.S. Counter
item.description: Deterring Moscow’s assault on Ukraine’s energy will pay off across Europe.

item.title: The constitutional dark arts spreading from Russia to the world
item.description: Concentrating vast power in one office to “save democracy” is the new authoritarian tactic of choice.

item.title: Allowing Nvidia to Sell H200 Chips to China Is a Mistake
item.description: The Trump administration’s decision risks undermining the U.S. in its protracted technology competition with China.

item.title: The Japanese Canary in the Global Debt Coal Mine
item.description: A prospective rise in Japanese interest rates could indicate that not only Japan, but also other heavily indebted economies, including the United States, could face sharply higher yields on government bonds. The only way out for Japan is to boost economic growth; but for the US, it is to raise taxes.

item.title: Nuclear Policy Must Learn to Live With Disagreement
item.description: From climate to AI, other fields have bridged deep divides.

item.title: Why China Is Watching Trump’s Venezuela Campaign Closely
item.description: U.S. intervention in Latin America could put China’s growing influence there in jeopardy. That might be the real goal.

item.title: The Best Treatment for the Most Painful Medical Condition Is Illegal
item.description: Sufferers of cluster headaches, also known as "suicide headaches," will do anything to stop what is possibly the most painful condition known to medicine, including using illegal drugs like psilocybin and LSD. Given strong evidence that psychedelics work, why aren't doctors allowed to prescribe them?

item.title: Why We Still Don’t Know Who the Rich Are in India
item.description: India has detailed systems for measuring poverty. But when it comes to wealth, the data goes dark.

item.title: China Bets on Unmanned Stealth Bombers
item.description: China’s focus on advanced UAVs offers critical insights into the People’s Liberation Army Air Force’s future airpower strategy.

item.title: The weekly cartoon
Business
Politics
Israel refuses to withdraw from Syria
item.description: That may create more enemies for the Jewish state

item.title: Donald Trump has not ended conflict between Congo and Rwanda
item.description: But making money may not require making peace

item.title: Nigeria’s kidnapping crisis
item.description: Donald Trump’s ire has drawn attention to appalling security failures

item.title: José Antonio Kast is Chile’s probable next president. How will he govern?
item.description: With a hyper-conservative president the country may be a test case for deportations, security crackdowns and spending cuts

item.title: The battle for Warner Bros is a prelude to the real streaming war
item.description: Professionally made shows face tough competition from independent makers

item.title: More reasons for America’s friends to plan for the worst
item.description: A strategy that scorns Europe, bullies Latin America and is vague on Asia

item.title: Australia’s hard right is resurgent
item.description: It includes actual Nazis

item.title: Hedging against Trump, Canada reconsiders ties with China
item.description: How far it can go will depend on America

item.title: Why do so many Chinese still smoke?
item.description: One reason: China’s tobacco industry has massive clout

item.title: Inside the fight for MAGA’s foreign policy
item.description: Donald Trump’s court squabbles over the future of American power

item.title: American doctors are rich and miserable
item.description: A recent study shows they are world leaders in burnout

item.title: How much does America know about its boat-strike targets?
item.description: Controversies about the lethal strikes touch on intelligence operations

item.title: All hail “The President of Peace”
item.description: But hold the prizes until Donald Trump actually delivers on his new branding

item.title: Ukraine’s trains, the country’s lifeline, have money problems
item.description: Russian drone attacks are only part of the problem

item.title: Albania is trying to charm its way into the EU
item.description: Edi Rama, the prime minister, is held back by his country’s corruption problems

item.title: Ukraine struggles to cope with America’s destructive peace plans
item.description: The latest manoeuvres by Donald Trump are familiar

item.title: Talks stall between Turkey’s government and the Kurds
item.description: The prize is the ending of four decades of war between the army and the PKK

item.title: A short guide to every business-hotel room
item.description: The world’s most commoditised experience

item.title: Vietnam’s EV champion is bleeding cash
item.description: VinFast is seeking salvation in foreign markets

item.title: A window of opportunity for reform in Lebanon is closing
item.description: Elections are looming, war drums are beating and the prime minister will soon be a lame duck

item.title: Precedent Points to a US War Crime in the Caribbean
item.description: During World War II, an Allied tribunal convicted German submariners of murdering shipwrecked survivors. In doing so, it set two clear precedents that the Trump administration seems to have overlooked in defending a "second strike" that killed alleged drug smugglers clinging to their capsized boat.

item.title: German Foreign Minister Wadephul (Finally) Visits China
item.description: After an earlier trip was postponed, his arrival in Beijing was a positive sign – but ties are not completely mended yet.

item.title: In Asia, Political Power Is for Sale. Can Global Action Finally Rein It in?
item.description: Governments must now choose: keep political money largely hidden, or adopt the basic transparency needed to sustain public trust.

item.title: Oracle and the hard truths about software
item.description: Running a giant digital business is not as fun as it used to be

item.title: America’s Supreme Court should strike down Donald Trump’s tariffs
item.description: The judges’ credibility is at stake

item.title: Germany has a lawyer problem
item.description: Its endless bureaucratic rules trap would-be reformers

item.title: What a stiff drink says about China’s economy
item.description: The baijiu business is the latest to be struck by “involution”

item.title: America’s bond market is quiet—almost too quiet
item.description: Scott Bessent has a cunning plan

item.title: Wall Street is drooling over bank mergers
item.description: The world’s most fragmented financial industry faces dramatic change

item.title: Can anyone stop Europe’s populist right?
item.description: Apocalyptic warnings by mainstream politicians are doomed to fail

item.title: The populists of Reform UK, already topping the polls, may climb higher
item.description: Claims that its support has peaked are probably wishful thinking

item.title: Once a pariah, the National Rally is now France’s most popular party
item.description: It could win the presidency in 2027 or parliamentary power even sooner

item.title: The Alternative for Germany is the leading party in some German polls
item.description: Despite retaining its far-right positions

item.title: How did one airline bring Indian aviation to its knees?
item.description: The blame is widely shared

item.title: Why many Asian megacities are miserable places
item.description: And why Shanghai and Tokyo are not

item.title: Building an Effective Sovereign Borrowers’ Club
item.description: Even though creditor coordination has long been institutionalized, borrower countries have often been discouraged from sharing information. Creating a mechanism that enables these countries to discuss technical issues, access capacity-building assistance, and coordinate actions would improve debt sustainability.

item.title: India Speeds Up Civil Nuclear Sector Privatization
item.description: While the government is yet to divulge details, it is considering legislative amendments to relax rules related to the liability of operators and suppliers

item.title: Did the Pakistan Army Sell Pakistani Neuroscientist Dr. Aafia Siddiqui to the US?
item.description: According to a human rights lawyer, the Pakistani army is not interested in securing her release, as that would implicate them in illegal activities they want to keep hidden.

item.title: Indonesia’s Floods: A Many-headed Serpent of Disaster
item.description: The immediate threat from Sumatra's floods and landslides may be over, but for many survivors the ordeal is only just beginning.

item.title: Don’t fear China’s trillion-dollar trade surplus
item.description: It is a problem not for the rest of the world, but for itself

item.title: Three Lessons China Learned from the United States
item.description: America’s greatest export was never democracy or consumer culture. It was the template for global power itself.

item.title: The Price of American Authoritarianism
item.description: What can reverse democratic decline?

item.title: Turkey’s Second Act
item.description: What a democratic restoration offers the country’s citizens—and the world.

item.title: Anwar Speaks to Leaders of Thailand, Cambodia as Border Conflict Rages
item.description: Compared to the fighting in July, there is a greater chance that the current conflict will be more protracted.

item.title: Support for Bougival Accord waning in New Caledonia
item.description: Noumea’s vote on the next step towards greater autonomy under the Accord reveals that divisions are deepening.
